data.title: J. J. Thomson Biography
data.meta_description: A behind-the-scene look at the life of J. J. Thomson.
data.text:
J. J. Thomson is known for his discovery of the electron, which revolutionized the field of physics.

J. J. Thomson conducted the cathode ray tube experiment, which led to the discovery of the electron.

J. J. Thomson's discovery of the electron provided evidence for the existence of subatomic particles and laid the foundation for the modern atomic theory.

The plum pudding model, proposed by J. J. Thomson, suggested that atoms consist of a positively charged sphere with negatively charged electrons embedded in it, resembling plums in a pudding.

J. J. Thomson's work on the electron paved the way for further research into subatomic particles and the development of quantum mechanics, leading to significant advancements in the field of physics.

Thomson was known for his love of cycling and often rode his bicycle to work at the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge.

Thomson had a fascination with puzzles and brain teasers and would often challenge his colleagues to solve them during breaks from his research.

Despite his groundbreaking work in physics, Thomson also had a passion for gardening and spent many hours cultivating his garden at home.
